G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as this is an action for damages not exceeding $50,000 arising from a violation of G.L. c. 186, §14.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as this is an action for damages not exceeding $50,000 arising from a violation of G.L. c. 186, §14.

*Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*.raw_text: *Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*, 424 Mass. 667, 670 (1997)
*Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court because the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Worcester County and the leased property is located in Worcester.
*Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*.case_name: 1010 Memorial Drive Tenants Corp. v. Fire Chief of Cambridge
*Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*.support_reasoning: The opinion in Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge concerns statutory interpretation of Massachusetts fire safety and sprinkler statutes as applied to cooperative vs. condominium ownership in a Cambridge building. It does not address venue, Worcester District Court, where acts or omissions occurred, or the location of leased property as a basis for venue. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about proper venue in Worcester District Court.
*Silva v. Rent Control Bd. of Cambridge*.relevant_excerpt: At issue is whether the owners of cooperative units located at 1010 Memorial Drive, in Cambridge, are required to comply with G. L. c. 148, § 26A1/2, by installing automatic sprinklers in each room of their residential units. The plaintiffs, owners of shares representing individual residential units, appeal from a determination by the Automatic Sprinkler Appeals Board (board) that G. L. c. 148, § 26A1/2, applies to their units and from a declaration by the Superior Court judge to the same effect... We reverse and remand to the Superior Court for a declaration that cooperatives are within the condominium exemption.

*G.L. c. 186, \u00a714*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 186, §14*, landlords are prohibited from directly or indirectly interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

*G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127L*.proposition: Plaintiff promptly notified Defendant of this condition, consistent with the reporting requirements under *G.L. c. 186, §14* and *G.L. c. 111, §127L*.

*105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.550*.proposition: The rodent infestation constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, *105 C.M.R. §410.550*, and renders the Premises unfit for human habitation.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in a habitable condition and to address known unsanitary conditions constitutes an unlawful interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that a landlord’s failure to act in the face of known conditions (drug activity making common areas unusable) can constitute a serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. However, the interference here is not framed as failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition or to address unsanitary conditions; rather, it is failure to take measures to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity. The court expressly rejects a habitability-based theory and instead grounds liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment tied to security/third-party crime, not unsanitary or physical habitability defects.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from conditions that materially impair their tenancy, including those violating the State Sanitary Code.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, defines it as protecting tenants from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, and then applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 to unsanitary flooding conditions that violated the State Sanitary Code (apartments must be watertight). It holds the landlord liable under § 14 because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions, and recognizes that ‘quiet enjoyment’ encompasses those habitability/sanitary violations that materially interfere with the tenancy.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from conditions that materially impair their tenancy, including those violating the State Sanitary Code.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether a lead paint statute violation, by itself, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that it does not. The court discusses that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct and landlord notice/foreseeability, but it does not state or elaborate that the covenant generally protects tenants from conditions materially impairing tenancy or specifically from all State Sanitary Code violations. The proposition is more general and about scope of protection, while this case is about the fault standard and the non-automatic linkage between another statutory violation and quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: In Simon v. Solomon, supra at 101, we interpreted the new statute and concluded with respect to civil liability it was not necessary for a tenant to show malicious intent to recover against a landlord; we said that the statute covered “at the least” the reckless conduct that had been shown in that case. Id. Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving “some degree of fault,” by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Conditions that persist after notice and deprive a tenant of freedom from disturbance or frustration of use amount to a breach under Massachusetts law.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that once the landlord has notice of conditions that render the premises uninhabitable, the tenant’s rent obligation abates immediately, regardless of the landlord’s fault or reasonable efforts to repair. The opinion explains that notice is required only to minimize the time the landlord is in breach, and that rent abatement begins when notice is given, not after a reasonable time to cure. This directly supports the proposition that conditions persisting after notice and depriving the tenant of the benefit of habitable, undisturbed use constitute a breach under Massachusetts law.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: "We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent. … Admittedly a tenant must notify her landlord of defects as a prerequisite to a rent abatement, but the purpose of this requirement is not to assure the landlord a reasonable time to repair. … The rent abatement begins when notice is given, not at a reasonable time after notice. Time for repairs has no place in the calculus."

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.raw_text: *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716–17 (1977) (landlord responsibility for foreseeable interference caused by its own acts or omissions)
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant, having notice and adequate time to act, failed to remedy the infestation and thereby constructively interrupted Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that a landlord who, through its own leasing decisions and subsequent failure to control conditions it has the right and ability to control, allows a serious interference to persist can be found to have constructively evicted tenants and to have breached quiet enjoyment. The court emphasizes that liability can arise from what the landlord "failed to do" after creating the situation and having the right to control it, which matches a theory that, after notice and time to act, failure to remedy an interference (here, noise; analogously, an infestation) constitutes constructive interruption of use and enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done…. Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.proposition: Defendant’s breach was willful in that he knowingly refrained from undertaking reasonable steps despite notice of continuing violations. *See* *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (1991).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss willful or knowing violations under Chapter 93A, but not in the specific sense claimed in the proposition. The cited page (around 871) concerns intentional infliction of emotional distress and whether such intentional conduct can constitute a willful or knowing Chapter 93A violation, not whether a defendant’s breach was willful because he knowingly refrained from reasonable remedial steps after notice of continuing violations. The case therefore does not articulate the proposed standard about knowingly failing to undertake reasonable steps despite notice.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.relevant_excerpt: “The likelihood that a finding of intentional infliction of emotional distress as a c. 93A violation will result in multiple damage awards pursuant to § 9 (3) is also no reason to bar such recovery. Such is the case in any intentionally wrongful act in violation of G.L.c. 93A, § 2. If a plaintiff’s proof in a c. 93A action includes proof of intent as part of an underlying theory of liability, that proof may satisfy the wilful-or-knowing requirement for an award of multiple damages under § 9 (3).”

*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated *G.L. c. 186, §14* and relevant case law including:    - *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (constructive interference from persistent water leaks);    - *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977);    - *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997);    - *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);    - *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979);    - *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (tenant entitled to damages for loss of quiet enjoyment);    - *McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300 (1999);    - *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985);    - *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987);    - *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (linking warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.support_reasoning: The proposition uses McAllister as authority that the defendant’s conduct *violated* G.L. c. 186, §14 and that the tenant was entitled to damages for loss of quiet enjoyment. McAllister holds the opposite: it affirms a directed verdict against the tenant on the quiet enjoyment claim, explicitly stating that negligence is a prerequisite to recovery under §14 and that the jury found no negligence. Thus, the case provides no support that the conduct violated §14 or that the tenant was entitled to damages; it instead limits such claims in these circumstances.
*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.relevant_excerpt: “We reject the plaintiff’s contention that she is entitled to a new trial based on her claims that the defendant violated the lease and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, G. L. c. 186, § 14. Negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under both theories. See Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997) (showing of negligence is required for recovery under quiet enjoyment statute)… The jury’s determination that the defendant was not negligent precludes the possibility that the directed verdicts on these claims constitute a basis for a new trial.”

*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated *G.L. c. 186, §14* and relevant case law including:    - *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (constructive interference from persistent water leaks);    - *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977);    - *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997);    - *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);    - *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979);    - *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (tenant entitled to damages for loss of quiet enjoyment);    - *McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300 (1999);    - *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985);    - *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987);    - *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (linking warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly upholds the trial judge’s finding that the landlord violated G.L. c. 186, §14, along with the warranty of habitability, and treats those violations as actionable and as constituting an unfair practice under c. 93A. The case thus stands as authority that the landlord’s pattern of uncorrected unsanitary conditions, leaks, inadequate security, and resulting interference with use of the premises can violate §14 and entitle the tenant to damages, including rent abatement and enhanced c. 93A remedies.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.relevant_excerpt: “Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, ‘also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.’ … The judge’s award based on a wilful or knowing violation is supported by evidence that the previous tenant… was unsuccessful in obtaining repairs and that some of the problems (leaks) had persisted for three and a half years and continued to the time of the trial in 1983.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated *G.L. c. 186, §14* and relevant case law including:    - *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (constructive interference from persistent water leaks);    - *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977);    - *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997);    - *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);    - *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979);    - *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (tenant entitled to damages for loss of quiet enjoyment);    - *McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300 (1999);    - *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985);    - *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987);    - *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (linking warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses warranty of habitability damages, security deposit penalties, rent control overcharges, and the landlord’s regulatory duty to provide heat and hot water, but it does not analyze or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 or the concept of interference with quiet enjoyment. The quiet enjoyment/§14 theory is not mentioned, and the court’s discussion of code violations is expressly framed under warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not §14 constructive interference case law. Thus the case does not provide authority for the specific §14-based proposition cited.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability.
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the ‘percentage reduction approach’ in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation. See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977). Although a detailed explanation of the trial judge’s calculations would have been preferable, an approximate dollar amount is permissible; damages in rent abatement cases generally are not capable of precise measurement.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.raw_text: *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (linking warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment)
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated *G.L. c. 186, §14* and relevant case law including:    - *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (constructive interference from persistent water leaks);    - *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977);    - *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997);    - *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);    - *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979);    - *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (tenant entitled to damages for loss of quiet enjoyment);    - *McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300 (1999);    - *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985);    - *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987);    - *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (linking warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted text is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, not the majority opinion, and it focuses on implied warranty of habitability and statutory code-based obligations rather than on G.L. c. 186, §14 or a doctrinal linkage between warranty of habitability and the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. While Hemingway as a whole is an important habitability/quiet enjoyment case, this specific excerpt does not discuss c. 186, §14, constructive interference, or quiet enjoyment damages, so it does not directly support the proposition as framed. Any linkage must be inferred from the broader decision, not from the reasoning quoted here.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court in the present cases does not discuss or otherwise deal with the rule quoted above from Palmigiani v. D’Argento... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant…”
